title: Can I be listed as a defendant when I was never notified (or served) that there was going to be a hearing?
question: In 2002, I had a credit card that was charged off. Last month, a collection agency took it upon themselves to pull the file and took it to court without notifying me. Court was held on May 5th . I found out about this from my company payroll dept who forwarded me a copy of the Whit of Execution with a Money Judgment to withhold funds from my payroll.
answers: Under the facts you listed about finding out about this from a wage garnishment, you have the right to set aside the default judgment and defend the case. You need to act promptly to do this. If the lawsuit was filed after the statute of limitations has expired, you also have the right to file a counter suit for collection abuse by this debt collector for suing you on a time-barred debt. Perhaps you should review my web site, below. Also, please take a look at my Avvo profile, as I have several legal guides, including negotiating with the debt collection law firm and about wage garnishment.

No, normally not but you can be served by substituted service or by publication with a court order so you may be unaware that you were served. Also, you should have been notified of a default hearing.
Yes the Statute of Limitations is 4 years.
You need an attorney to file a "Motion to Vacate an Order for Execution and Quash the Executon" like now.

A person can be listed/named as a defendant in the lawsuit without being notified, but that does not make the result valid. You must be properly served with notice of the lawsuit and given an opportunity to appear and defend yourself. As the prior answer indicates, if that did not occur, a motion to set aside the verdict should be filed based on the defense of improper service. If successful, this would negate the writ and cause the plaintiff to refile the case (or it so chooses) and provide proper notice to you.

A "write off" is just an internal accounting technique that doesn't mean that your debt is gone and that no one will try to collect it, and in CA, the statute of limitations on written contracts is 4 years form the date of breach, which is often the date of your last payment, so if your last payment was made in 2006 or later, this debt may still be actionable.

But chances seem good that the statute may have run on this debt, and you may have a good defense to this claim. The creditor or their collection agency CAN'T sue you without serving you with process (meaning with the court documents), so you have a chance to defend yourself. If this creditor/agency got a default judgment against you and is executing on that judgment by garnishing your wages, you need to vacate (undo) that judgment ASAP and stop this garnishment.

These are relatively complicated processes, so hire a lawyer for help.

The Plaintiff cannot get a judgment against you without your being personally served with the Summons and Complaint. You have to go to court and file a motion to set aside the judgment under Code of Civil Procedure Section 473.

There is a 4-year statute of limitations per CCP Section 337. If the debt was written off in 2002 they would have had to file suit in 2006. This is a defense you should mention in your 473 motion and the answer that has to be attached to the motion.
